bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Commanding Officer, Carlisle Barracks, June 25, 1940

div1.p: Hench requests photographs of a model of Camp Columbia, which is now at Carlisle Barracks, Pennsylvania, and other information about Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Commanding Officer, Carlisle Barracks, June 25, 1940
div1.opener:
Y. F.
June 25, 1940
Commanding Officer
Carlisle Barracks
Carlisle, Pennsylvania
My dear Sir:
div1.p:
I have been doing some historical researches on the work of Walter Reed
and the yellow fever board at Camp Columbia, Havana, in 1900. Colonel Ash and
Major H. A. Davis of the Army Medical Museum in Washington have given me much
help and last week when I was in Washington they showed me photographs of a model
of Camp Columbia made by some Cuban in 1900. This model, formerly at the Army
Medical Museum, I understand is now at the Carlisle Barracks. They have a photo-
graph of the side of the model and one looking down on the top. Do you still have
this model and would it be possible to get a photograph looking down on it from
the front? Major Davis thought that you had a staff photographer, who might be
willing and able to make this for me. In reciprocity for the great kindness of
the staff of the Army Medical Museum in providing me with these various photographs
I was delighted to promise them that they will receive copies of the documentary
evidence and various photographs that I have collected from various survivors of
the yellow fever experiments. As a result of a visit to Havana and elsewhere, we have
discovered several very important things.

First of all, the Cuban government has chosen the wrong site of Camp
Lazear. The one that they now have marked Camp Lazear is entirely wrong and we
found this out just in time, as they had planned to build a memorial building on
the wrong site. The site they have wrongly chosen is right across the railroad
track from the present military city, which is on the site of Camp Columbia.
This railroad track is visible in the model which you possess. On this site is
not Camp Lazear but a small group of tents comprising a tent hospital where they
brought the victims of yellow fever after they had contracted it at Camp Lazear
a mile away. Any help that you can give me will be much appreciated.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
